Knowledge Point: The most commonly attested alternative to the nominative/accusative system is called an ergative/absolutive system. In this way of organizing grammatical relations, the S and O are treated as “the same” grammatical relation, whereas the A is treated distinctly for purposes of case marking, pronominal form and other grammatical features. If any grammatical relation includes A alone it can be called the ergative relation\is{case!ergative}\is{ergative case}, and any grammatical relation that encompasses S and O can be termed the absolutive relation\is{case!absolutive}\is{absolutive case}. This is the system exhibited in basic clauses of many languages of the world, including Kagayanen. The examples in \REF{bkm:Ref482781620} illustrate an ergative/absolutive system in personal pronouns\is{ergative/absolutive system}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: and \REF{ex:padakeptapulismatakawan}. However, the phrases preceded by ta do not have the same structural properties of A arguments in examples \REF{ex:padakeptapulismatakawan} and \REF{ex:padakeptapulismatakawan}. The ta-marked argument in \REF{bkm:Ref482789597} is in a different grammatical relation. We know this for several reasons. First, when non-agent arguments are pronominalized, they do not occur in the case we have identified as “ergative” above.
Content 1: \gsrc Gadakep pulis an ta matakaw. | \gll Ga-dakep pulis an ta matakaw. | \gls I.R-catch police DEF.M NABS thief | \glt ‘The police caught/are catching a/the thief/thieves.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref118364790v} the root tan-aw ‘to look’ describes an activity that necessarily involves an Actor (the looker) and an Undergoer (the thing looked at). However, in this example, the verb is marked as intransitive, and the Actor, “we”, is in the absolutive case. Like all intransitive clauses, this is a statement about the referent of the absolutive element; it is not about the particular movie. The Undergoer is mentioned, but in a non-absolutive role marked by the prenominal case marker ta. The story goes on to talk about the Actors going home and then going other places.
Content 1: \gsrc Pagtapos nay igma, gatan-aw kay ta sini. | \gll Pag-tapos nay igma, ga-tan-aw kay ta sini. | \gls NR.ACT-finish 1P.EXCL.ERG lunch I.R-look 1P.EXCL.ABS NABS movie | \glt ‘After we finished lunch, we were watching a movie.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, example \REF{bkm:Ref117000014} is about the unstated absolutive participant, “us”, and not about any particular trees. Again, as in all intransitive constructions, the absolutive is presented as the most salient or highly affected participant in the situation being described. The Undergoer is presented in a less “privileged” syntactic role. In fact, in such constructions, the Undergoer is often omitted altogether, as in example \REF{bkm:Ref117000205} further below.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Dili ka mabutaļ daw naan ta lamisaan na gakaan. | \gll Dili ka ma-butaļ daw naan ta lamisa-an na ga-kaan. | \gls NEG.IR 2S.ABS A.HAP.IR-fight if/when SPAT.DEF NABS table-NR LK I.R-eat | \glt `You should not fight/argue when at the table when eating.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{bkm:Ref117000354} there is no particular orchid flower on stage in the situation being described. Rather the speaker is saying something about “you”. Seeing an orchid flower in the wild is more likely to affect the person than the flower.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Finally, in example \REF{bkm:Ref117000205}, there are two verbs that have the same absolutive argument, the enclitic ka ‘you’. Both verbs butaļ ‘fight’ and kaan ‘eat’ describe semantically transitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} situations – fighting involves at least two people, and eating necessarily involves an eater and something that gets eaten. Yet each of these verbs is presented as grammatically intransitive with no mention of any Undergoer. This is because this is an admonition from a parent to a child about how the child should behave. It is all about the Actor, and not about any particular Undergoer.
Content 1: \gsrc Dili ka mabutaļ daw naan ta lamisaan na gakaan. | \gll Dili ka ma-butaļ daw naan ta lamisa-an na ga-kaan. | \gls NEG.IR 2S.ABS A.HAP.IR-fight if/when SPAT.DEF NABS table-NR LK I.R-eat | \glt `You should not fight/argue when at the table when eating.'

Knowledge Point: Detransitive constructions such as these serve a communicative function that is similar to what have been called “Oblique Object” or “Object Omission” constructions in English, illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref117062761}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Finally, some linguists have argued that the Undergoer in examples such as \REF{bkm:Ref482789597} and \REF{ex:gadakeppulisankikanen} is not an oblique argument at all, but is a core argument, similar to a direct object (see, e.g., \citealt{kroeger1993, foley2008} for other Philippine languages). In Kagayanen, there is no doubt that the demoted Undergoer in a detransitive construction is structurally distinct from other oblique elements. For example, demoted Undergoers cannot naturally be expressed before the verb:
Content 1: \gsrc Gadakep pulis an ta matakaw. | \gll Ga-dakep pulis an ta matakaw. | \gls I.R-catch police DEF.M NABS thief | \glt ‘The police caught/are catching a/the thief/thieves.’

Knowledge Point: However, in \REF{bkm:Ref497135842} and \REF{bkm:Ref497135845}, the spatial element naan must occur before the fronted oblique phrase. These examples are as ungrammatical as \REF{bkm:Ref497135886} if naan is omitted. In fact, it is very odd for any non-absolutive RP to be fronted without including naan, though they may occur post-verbally without it:
Content 1: \gsrc Naan ta uma nay patanem nay kamuti an. | \gll Naan ta uma nay pa-tanem nay kamuti an. | \gls SPAT.DEF NABS field 1P.EXCL.ERG T.R-plant 1P.EXCL.ERG camote DEF.M | \glt ‘In our field we planted camote.’
Content 2: \gsrc Naan ki kanen paatag ko bayo no ya. | \gll Naan ki kanen pa-atag ko bayo no ya. | \gls SPAT.DEF OBL.P 3s T.R-give 1S.ERG clothes 2S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘To him/her I gave your shirt/clothes.’

Knowledge Point: In an intransitive clause, there is only one Referring Expression that has a grammatical relation to the Predicate. Any additional elements are optional. Referring Expressions that have a grammatical relation to the Predicate are called arguments\is{arguments}, or sometimes core arguments\is{core arguments}. In each of these examples, the absolutive is the only argument of the clause. It is marked as absolutive by either the lack of a prenominal case marker (\ref{bkm:Ref116980651} and \ref{bkm:Ref116980654}), or the absolutive form of a pronoun (\ref{bkm:Ref116980701}, \ref{bkm:Ref116980703} and \ref{bkm:Ref116980658}). In all the verbal predicates (\ref{bkm:Ref116980651}-\ref{bkm:Ref116980703}), the verb is marked as intransitive, either realis (\ref{bkm:Ref116980651}, \ref{bkm:Ref116980654} and \ref{bkm:Ref116980701}), or irrealis (twice in \ref{bkm:Ref116980703}). Example \ref{bkm:Ref116980658} is a non-verbal predicate. Non-verbal predicates\is{non-verbal predicates} are always intransitive, and are not marked for transitivity or modality (see \chapref{chap:non-verbalclauses}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In all of these constructions (\ref{bkm:Ref116980651}-\ref{bkm:Ref116980658}), the speaker is making a statement about the absolutive case argument. The absolutive argument is presented as the person or thing that is most relevant or most highly affected by the situation described in the Predicate. It is very common for the absolutive argument of an intransitive clause to be a semantic Actor (\ref{bkm:Ref116980651}-\ref{bkm:Ref116980703}), but this is not always true. Example \REF{bkm:Ref116980658} illustrates a clause in which the absolutive does not do anything. It is not an Actor because it does not initiate or control the event. Intransitive verbal predicates in happenstantial modalities\is{happenstantial modality} also express situations in which the absolutive argument is not an Actor:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: There is a difference between \isi{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} and \isi{grammatical transitivity}\is{transitivity!grammatical}. As mentioned in \sectref{bkm:Ref482605816}, a situation that seems to require an Undergoer and a distinct Controller may be expressed in an intransitive construction, with the Undergoer simply omitted or expressed in a non-absolutive case, preceded by ta or ki. We describe such constructions as detransitive\is{detransitive constructions}. They express semantically transitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} situations in grammatically intransitive frames. Such constructions are used when there is an Undergoer, but it is less salient in the communicative situation than the Actor in some way. The Actor is presented as the most affected participant in the situation, and the Undergoer, if present at all, is presented as less central in some way, either by being indefinite, non-specific, generic or incompletely affected. Examples of detransitive constructions in the corpus are presented in \ref{bkm:Ref125017724v}-\ref{bkm:Ref117000205} above.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Dili ka mabutaļ daw naan ta lamisaan na gakaan. | \gll Dili ka ma-butaļ daw naan ta lamisa-an na ga-kaan. | \gls NEG.IR 2S.ABS A.HAP.IR-fight if/when SPAT.DEF NABS table-NR LK I.R-eat | \glt `You should not fight/argue when at the table when eating.'

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Benefactive voice often functions to express situations in which something is transferred to a beneficiary, with the beneficiary presented in the absolutive case (examples \ref{bkm:Ref500489993} and \ref{bkm:Ref500489123}). However, transfer is not a necessary component of the meaning of this construction (examples \ref{ex:thecabinet} through \ref{ex:thetikling}).
Content 1: \gsrc Paakiran ko \emptyset{} \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gll Pa-akid-an ko ∅ \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gls T.R-serve-APL 1S.ERG ABS 3S.ABS DEF.M NABS fish | \glt ‘I served \textbf{her/him} some fish.’
Content 2: \gsrc Lutuan ko \emptyset{} \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gll ∅-Luto-an ko ∅ \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gls T.IR-cook-APL 1S.ERG ABS 3S.ABS DEF.M NABS fish | \glt ‘I will cook \textbf{him/her} some fish.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Without the applicative marker on the verb, example \REF{bkm:Ref500489123} could only be understood as patient voice, which would be anomalous with these arguments: “I will cook him/her (with/on/by) fish.”
Content 1: \gsrc Lutuan ko \emptyset{} \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gll ∅-Luto-an ko ∅ \textbf{kanen} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gls T.IR-cook-APL 1S.ERG ABS 3S.ABS DEF.M NABS fish | \glt ‘I will cook \textbf{him/her} some fish.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: As discussed in \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, \sectref{sec:modality} the Deontic prefix i- may function as an applicative marker, as in \REF{bkm:Ref500489008}. As such, i- may function as a deontic Benefactive marker:
Content 1: \gsrc Iluto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gll I-luto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gls T.DEON-cook 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS fish | \glt ‘You must cook \textbf{me} some fish.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Technically, \ref{bkm:Ref500489008} is ambiguous between Benefactive and Patient voice. However, pragmatically it can only be understood as Benefactive voice, since people don’t cook other people. We are reminded of English sentences like “I will make you a sandwich” which are similarly “ambiguous”. The usage illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref500489008} has also been described as “conveyance voice” in \isi{Cebuano} based on the fact that it presents the Undergoer (sidda ‘fish’) as moving away from the Actor \citep[69]{wolff1973}.
Content 1: \gsrc Iluto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gll I-luto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gls T.DEON-cook 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS fish | \glt ‘You must cook \textbf{me} some fish.’
Content 2: \gsrc Iluto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gll I-luto \textbf{a} no ta sidda. | \gls T.DEON-cook 1S.ABS 2S.ERG NABS fish | \glt ‘You must cook \textbf{me} some fish.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref500490084} through \REF{bkm:Ref500742432} illustrate Locative voice. Again, these are only understood as locative because of the context. In \REF{bkm:Ref500490084}, for example, the plate cannot logically be a beneficiary, but rather is a logical location for serving something:
Content 1: \gsrc Paakiran ko \textbf{pinggan no an} ta sidda. | \gll Pa-akid-an ko ∅ \textbf{pinggan} \textbf{no} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gls T.R-serve-APL 1S.ERG ABS plate 2S.GEN DEF.M NABS fish | \glt ‘I served on \textbf{your plate} some fish.’
Content 2: \gsrc Lutuan ko \textbf{bakod} \textbf{an} \textbf{na} \textbf{kandwagan} ta sidda para ta bisita. | \gll ∅-Luto-an ko ∅ \textbf{bakod} \textbf{an} \textbf{na} \textbf{kandwagan} ta sidda para ta bisita. | \gls T.IR-cook-APL 1S.ERG ABS big DEF.M LK skillet NABS fish for NABS visitor | \glt ‘I will cook in \textbf{the big skillet} some fish for the visitor.’
Content 3: \gsrc Paakiran ko \textbf{pinggan no an} ta sidda. | \gll Pa-akid-an ko ∅ \textbf{pinggan} \textbf{no} \textbf{an} ta sidda. | \gls T.R-serve-APL 1S.ERG ABS plate 2S.GEN DEF.M NABS fish | \glt ‘I served on \textbf{your plate} some fish.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: We are calling example \REF{bkm:Ref500490264} Locative voice because the younger sibling is presented as the target of laughing. This sentence cannot be understood as Benefactive voice (“He laughed for my younger sibling”), even though the absolutive argument is animate and human.
Content 1: \gsrc Patawaan din \textbf{mangngod} \textbf{ko} an. | \gll Pa-tawa-an din ∅ \textbf{mangngod} \textbf{ko} an. | \gls T.R-laugh-APL 3S.ERG ABS younger.sibling 1S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he laughed at my younger sibling.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref118204268} illustrates an applicative construction inside a relative clause. The head is basak ‘land’, which is the location of planting.
Content 1: \gsrc Kami may basak \textbf{nataneman} nay ta niog. | \gll Kami may basak \textbf{na-tanem-an} nay ta niog. | \gls 1P.EXCL.ABS EXT.IN land A.HAP.R-plant-APL 1P.EXCL.ERG NABS coconut | \glt ‘As for us (we) have land on which we have planted coconut trees.’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref118204368} the composite pronoun ta kaw expresses a first person singular ergative plus second person singular absolutive argument (see \chapref{chap:referringexpressions}, \sectref{sec:pronouns} on the composite pronouns):
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref118204569} illustrates three applicative constructions. The first applicative involves the root ibit ‘hold’, which is a member of the class of roots that always appear in an applicative form when transitive (Class VIII). All such roots involve a patient that does not undergo a change in state, but is only slightly, superficially or invisibly affected by the action of the verb. In this case, the act of holding a child does not change or affect the child in any substantive way, and thus the child shares the semantic feature of “superficial affectedness” with locations. \chapref{chap:verbclasses-1}, \sectref{sec:volitionaltransitiveroots} contains a long list of such roots. In the second applicative in \REF{bkm:Ref118204569}, the location of the placing of water is the head of the child, which appears in the absolutive. Finally, in the third applicative, the absolutive argument of the stem garayan ‘to chant for’ is ellipted because the child is the main topic in this stretch of text, and in the context it is clear that the midwife chants for the child.
Content 1: \gsrc Nanligan i \textbf{pabitan} din bata daw \textbf{batangan} ta waig a ulo ta bata. Tapos \textbf{pagarayan} din.\\ | \gll Nanligan i \textbf{pa-ibit-an} din bata daw ...-\textbf{batang-an} ta waig a ulo ta bata. Tapos \textbf{pa-garay-an} din.\\ | \gls midwife DEF.N T.R-hold-APL 3S.ERG child and T.R-put-APL NABS water INJ head NABS child then T.R-chant-APL 3S.ERG | \glt `As for the midwife, she holds the child and puts some water on the head of the child. Then she chants (for the child).’ (This is a naming ceremony for newborn babies similar to baptism.)
Content 2: \gsrc Nanligan i \textbf{pabitan} din bata daw \textbf{batangan} ta waig a ulo ta bata. Tapos \textbf{pagarayan} din.\\ | \gll Nanligan i \textbf{pa-ibit-an} din bata daw ...-\textbf{batang-an} ta waig a ulo ta bata. Tapos \textbf{pa-garay-an} din.\\ | \gls midwife DEF.N T.R-hold-APL 3S.ERG child and T.R-put-APL NABS water INJ head NABS child then T.R-chant-APL 3S.ERG | \glt `As for the midwife, she holds the child and puts some water on the head of the child. Then she chants (for the child).’ (This is a naming ceremony for newborn babies similar to baptism.)

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref118208801} illustrates a happenstantial irrealis modality Adversative applicative construction from the corpus. We know the prefix on the bolded verb has been dropped because adlaw `sun/day' used as a verb meaning `become daylight' must take happenstantial modality. The prefix ma- may be added, with no change in meaning, but the dynamic intransitive irrealis prefixes mag- or m- are impossible:
Content 1: \gsrc Maria, pilak no duma an na suwa tak kani \textbf{adlawan ki en}. | \gll Maria, pilak no duma an na suwa tak kani ...\textbf{-adlaw-an} \textbf{ki en}. | \gls Maria throw.away 2S.ERG some DEF.M LK citrus.fruit because later A.HAP.IR-sun/day-APL 1P.INCL.ABS CM | \glt `Maria, throw away some of the citrus fruit because later it will become daytime on us.’ (This is a story about a mother, who is a witch, and her daughter. They were invisible flying home carrying citrus fruit. So the mother tells the daughter to throw away some of the fruit so they will not be seen.)

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref500573274} and \REF{bkm:Ref500573276} have the same argument structure--an Actor in the ergative case and a patient in the absolutive, therefore they are both patient voice. The difference is that \REF{bkm:Ref500573274} is a simple transitive construction, while \REF{bkm:Ref500573276} is an applicative. The meaning of \REF{bkm:Ref500573276} is that the Actor did not cut the wood completely in two parts, but only cut off a small portion. The following examples, repeated here from \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, also illustrate the partitive use of the applicative. Example \REF{bkm:Ref395171869} illustrates the verb panno ‘fill’ in a non-applicative construction. In this example, the shirt is the absolutive, while the Actor, ‘he’ is ergative:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 6: \gsrc \textbf{Papanno} din bayo din ya ta bļawan | \gll \textbf{Pa-panno} din bayo din ya ta bļawan… | \gls T.R-fill 3S.ERG shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F NABS gold | \glt ‘He filled up his shirt with gold...’

Subsection: Applicative constructions (Benefactive, Adversative, and Locative voice)
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref395171874v} illustrates the same verb in an applicative construction. Note, however, that the argument structure is the same. The shirt is still absolutive, and the Actor is still ergative:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Papannuan} din bayo din ya ta bļawan. | \gll \textbf{Pa-panno-an} din bayo din ya ta bļawan. | \gls T.R-fill-APL 3S.ERG shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F NABS gold | \glt ‘He filled part way his shirt with gold.’

Knowledge Point: In irrealis modality, however, instrumental voice is distinguished by the presence of the transitive deontic prefix i-. In such situations, the -i prefix has an instrumental applicative function, as in \REF{ex:servesomefish} and \REF{bkm:Ref500142287}:
Content 1: \gsrc Iprito ko bag-o i na mantika ta sidda. | \gll I-prito ko ∅ bag-o i na mantika ta sidda. | \gls T.DEON-fry 1S.ERG ABS new DEF.N LK oil NABS fish | \glt ‘I must use the new oil to fry some fish.’

Knowledge Point: Again, in transitive irrealis modality without the i- prefix, example \REF{bkm:Ref500142287} becomes anomalous (??‘I will fry the new oil for/to/with fish.’). Because the absolutive nominal can be construed as an instrument in each instance, the only possibility is Instrumental voice.
Content 1: \gsrc Iprito ko bag-o i na mantika ta sidda. | \gll I-prito ko ∅ bag-o i na mantika ta sidda. | \gls T.DEON-fry 1S.ERG ABS new DEF.N LK oil NABS fish | \glt ‘I must use the new oil to fry some fish.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to these lexical causative verbs, Kagayanen has several verbs that function as \isi{syntactic causatives}. These verbs evoke the notion of cause, while the effect is expressed in a separate verb in irrealis modality.\footnote{We term this use of the irrealis modality “subjunctive”\is{subjunctive} (see \chapref{chap:clausecombining}, \sectref{sec:subjunctiveclauses}).} A few of these verbs are listed in \REF{bkm:Ref501085954}, and some examples from the texts are given below, beginning with \REF{bkm:Ref501085964}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The most productive means of forming a causative construction in Kagayanen is morphologically,\is{morphological causatives} expressed with the verbal prefix pa{}-. This is a very common stem-forming prefix, as discussed in \chapref{chap:stemformingprocesses}, \sectref{sec:morphologicalcausative}. A few common non-caus\-a\-tive{\slash}morphological causative verb pairs are given in \REF{bkm:Ref501438581}. However, the causative prefix may be added to practically any root to form a transitive, causative verb stem. Meanings expressed by the morphological causative include ‘to cause someone to do something’, ‘to ask someone to do something’, ‘to let someone or something do something’, ‘to make it possible for someone to do something’, or ‘just wait for someone to do something or something to happen.’
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, \sectref{sec:transitiverealis}, the causative prefix pa{}- is homophonous with the transitive realis Inflectional prefix. Therefore, one transitive verb with pa{}- can have two meanings: one simple transitive \REF{bkm:Ref501092121} and the other causative \REF{bkm:Ref329253035}.
Content 1: \gsrc Pasuot din bayo din ya. | \gll Pa-suot din bayo din ya. | \gls T.R-wear 3S.ERG clothes/shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘S/he wore his/her shirt.’
Content 2: \gsrc ...-Pasuot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gll pa-pa-suot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gls T.R-CAUS-wear 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s clothes/shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘S/he let me wear his/her shirt.’

Knowledge Point: It is clear, however, that there are two distinct pa{}- morphemes for at least two reasons. First, example \REF{bkm:Ref329253035} is ditransitive--it has three arguments: a causer din '3serg', a causee ki yaken `\textsc{obl.p 1s}', and a patient bayo din ya `shirt 3\textsc{s.erg def.f}'. This can only be understood as causative. The only non-causative interpretation would be “s/he wore his/her shirt to/on me”, which makes no sense. Example \REF{bkm:Ref501092121}, on the other hand, has only two arguments, and may not be understood as causative (*‘S/he made the shirt wear something’ ...). Second, it is possible for both pa{}- morphemes to occur on the same verb:
Content 1: \gsrc ...-Pasuot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gll pa-pa-suot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gls T.R-CAUS-wear 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s clothes/shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘S/he let me wear his/her shirt.’
Content 2: \gsrc Pasuot din bayo din ya. | \gll Pa-suot din bayo din ya. | \gls T.R-wear 3S.ERG clothes/shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘S/he wore his/her shirt.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \chapref{chap:verbstructure} \sectref{sec:omissionofprefixes}, sequences of double pa- often simplify. However, when a double pa- does occur, it expresses a stronger causative, as roughly reflected in the English free translations of \REF{bkm:Ref329253035} and \REF{ex:his/hershirt}.
Content 1: \gsrc ...-Pasuot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gll pa-pa-suot din ki yaken bayo din ya. | \gls T.R-CAUS-wear 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s clothes/shirt 3S.GEN DEF.F | \glt ‘S/he let me wear his/her shirt.’

Knowledge Point: With ditransitive verb roots, when there is only one pa{}- it is the transitive, realis prefix \REF{bkm:Ref236213080}. For the causative, the shortened form is not normally used, probably for clarity \REF{bkm:Ref329253571}, but it can be used in fast speech.
Content 1: \gsrc Pabligya din ki yaken baboy din an. | \gll Pa-bligya din ki yaken baboy din an. | \gls T.R-sell 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s pig 3S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he sold his/her pig to me.’
Content 2: \gsrc Papabligya din ki yaken baboy din an. | \gll Pa-pa-bligya din ki yaken baboy din an. | \gls T.R-CAUS-sell 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s pig 3S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he made/let me sell his/her pig.’

Knowledge Point: As with all semantically transitive\is{semantic transitivity}\is{transitivity!semantic} verbs, causative verb stems can appear in a Detransitive (Actor voice) construction. In this case, the pa{}- causative does appear with some verbs (such as lunot `decay' in example \ref{bkm:Ref501112712}) but not with others (such as pudpod, ‘crumble into powder’ in example \ref{bkm:Ref329259219}):
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Gapalunot} kanen ta tampayas. | \gll \textbf{Ga-pa-lunot} kanen ta tampayas. | \gls I.R-CAUS-decay 3S.ABS NABS papaya | \glt ‘S/he let/caused the papaya to decay.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Gapudpod} kanen an ta buļong. | \gll \textbf{Ga-pudpod} kanen an ta buļong. | \gls I.R-crumble.into.powder 3S.ABS DEF.M NABS medicine | \glt ‘S/he is/was crumbling medicine into powder.’

Knowledge Point: We know that \REF{bkm:Ref329259219} is a detransitive of a causative construction and not a simple intransitive construction because a) the absolutive pronoun refers to a person, and persons don’t (normally) crumble into powder, and b) the understanding is that the medicine is what crumbles, with the absolutive argument referring to a causal agent.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Gapudpod} kanen an ta buļong. | \gll \textbf{Ga-pudpod} kanen an ta buļong. | \gls I.R-crumble.into.powder 3S.ABS DEF.M NABS medicine | \glt ‘S/he is/was crumbling medicine into powder.’

Knowledge Point: We know that the pa{}- prefix is a causative, and the modality is irrealis in \REF{bkm:Ref501176811} because of the argument structure. The presence of an oblique argument, ki yaken, makes it clear that this is a double causative. The absence of an overt transitivity marker on the verb indicates that this must be irrealis modality (recall that the presence of the applicative -an precludes the use of the transitive irrealis suffix -en, thus leaving “zero” as the only indicator of transitivity). If the pa{}- in this example were the transitive realis pa{}-, the only possible reading would be “You brought the driftwood to the beach at me,” and such a meaning is impossible.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Padagsaan} din ki yaken \textbf{baybay} \textbf{an} ta mga batang. | \gll ∅-\textbf{Pa-dagsa-an} din ki yaken \textbf{baybay} \textbf{an} ta mga batang. | \gls T.IR-CAUS-wash.ashore-APL 3S.ERG OBL.P 1s beach DEF.M NABS PL driftwood | \glt `S/he will make me let some driftwood wash ashore on the beach.’

Knowledge Point: The detransitive causative of some verbs has a reflexive sense, since the causer and the patient may be coreferential (\ref{bkm:Ref329267348}). The meaning is ‘to let oneself have something done to oneself.’ A distinct causee can occur optionally in an oblique phrase, as in \REF{bkm:Ref329267373} and \REF{bkm:Ref329267376}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Magpasagod} ka nang en daw manakem ka. | \gll \textbf{Mag-pa-sagod} ka nang en daw manakem ka. | \gls I.IR-CAUS-take.care 2S.ABS just CM if/when older 2S.ABS | \glt ‘Just have yourself taken care of when you are elderly.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Gapabuļong} a naan ta duktor. | \gll \textbf{Ga-pa-buļong} a naan ta duktor. | \gls I.R-CAUS-medicine 1S.ABS SPAT.DEF NABS doctor | \glt ‘I am/was having myself medicated by the doctor.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Gapaluko} ka nang imo ta yo na ittaw. | \gll \textbf{Ga-pa-luko} ka nang imo ta yo na ittaw. | \gls I.R-CAUS-trick 2S.ABS just EMPH NABS D4ADJ LK person | \glt ‘You just let yourself be tricked by that person.'

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref108689939} illustrates two instances of this “reflexive/causative” usage for two other verbs, kita ‘to see’ and kasaļ ‘to marry’:
Content 1: \gsrc Sabat ta pangka ya, “\textbf{Magpakita} a ta imo na mga ginikanan daw ambaļen ko danen na \textbf{magpakasaļ} \textbf{ki}." | \gll Sabat ta pangka ya, “\textbf{Mag-pa-kita} a ta imo na mga ginikanan daw ambaļ-en ko danen na \textbf{mag-pa-kasaļ} \textbf{ki}." | \gls answer NASB frog DEF.F I.IR-CAUS-see 1S.ABS NABS 2S.GEN LK PL parent and say-T.IR 1S.ERG 3P.ABS LK I.IR-CAUS-wedding 1P.INCL.ABS | \glt `The frog answered, “I will \textbf{show} myself to your parents and I will tell them that we are \textbf{going} \textbf{to} \textbf{get} \textbf{(ourselves)} \textbf{wedded/married}.”'

Knowledge Point: Except for these lexical reflexives, and the extended use of causative morphology to express a kind of reflexive described in the previous section, most reflexive constructions in Kagayanen are syntactic. They consist of a transitive or detransitive construction with a possessed Referring Phrase headed either by kaugalingen ‘self’ or lawa ‘body’ occurring in the Undergoer role. These may either be transitive (\ref{bkm:Ref118617763}), or detransitive (\ref{bkm:Ref118617766}):
Content 1: \gsrc Panina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gll Pa-nina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gls T.R-wound 3S.ERG body 3S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he wounded him/herself.’ (lit. ’S/he wounded her/his own body.’)
Content 2: \gsrc Gaugas kanen ta \textbf{kaugalingen} \textbf{din}. | \gll Ga-ugas kanen ta \textbf{kaugalingen} \textbf{din}. | \gls I.R-wash 3S.ABS NABS self 3S.GEN | \glt ‘S/he washed her/himself.’

Knowledge Point: These examples must be understood as reflexive; the possessor of the Undergoer may not refer to a distinct person. In other words, \REF{bkm:Ref118617763} cannot mean `S/he wounded someone else's body’. Kaugalingen is the dedicated reflexive nominal. Lawa ’physical body’ is sometimes used in place of kaugalingen, possibly because it is shorter.
Content 1: \gsrc Panina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gll Pa-nina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gls T.R-wound 3S.ERG body 3S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he wounded him/herself.’ (lit. ’S/he wounded her/his own body.’)

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref118617763} and \REF{bkm:Ref118618251}-\REF{bkm:Ref118618196} show that ergative case Actors may antecede absolutive case reflexive RPs. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref118617766} and \REF{bkm:Ref501865097} illustrate that an absolutive Actor (ka ‘you’) may be the antecedent for a reflexive Referring Phrase in a detransitive construction:
Content 1: \gsrc Panina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gll Pa-nina din \textbf{lawa} \textbf{din} \textbf{an}. | \gls T.R-wound 3S.ERG body 3S.GEN DEF.M | \glt ‘S/he wounded him/herself.’ (lit. ’S/he wounded her/his own body.’)
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Iran} \textbf{nang} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen} isip ya danen. | \gll \textbf{Iran} \textbf{nang} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen} isip ya danen. | \gls 3P.GEN only LK self think DEF.F 3P.ERG | \glt ‘Themselves only is what they think about.’
Content 3: \gsrc Piro gusto ko gid anay ipakilala ko \textbf{ake} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen}. | \gll Piro gusto ko gid anay i-pa-kilala ko \textbf{ake} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen}. | \gls but want 1S.ERG INT first/for.awhile T.DEON-CAUS-know 1S.ERG 1S.GEN LK self | \glt ‘But I really want to first have to introduce myself.’ (kilala is code switching from \isi{Tagalog}.)
Content 4: \gsrc Gaugas kanen ta \textbf{kaugalingen} \textbf{din}. | \gll Ga-ugas kanen ta \textbf{kaugalingen} \textbf{din}. | \gls I.R-wash 3S.ABS NABS self 3S.GEN | \glt ‘S/he washed her/himself.’
Content 5: \gsrc Dili ka gid dyan magpabaya ta \textbf{imo} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen}. | \gll Dili ka gid dyan mag-pa-baya ta \textbf{imo} \textbf{na} \textbf{kaugalingen}. | \gls NEG,IR 2S.ABS INT D4LOC I.IR-CAUS-ignore NABS 2S.GEN LK self | \glt ‘Do not just ignore yourself there.’

Knowledge Point: Though kaugalingen is the dedicated reflexive nominal, there is evidence that the meaning of lawa is also becoming a dedicated reflexive itself. Example \REF{bkm:Ref118699324} shows that lawa does not always refer literally to someone’s physical body.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref118618209} illustrates the \isi{Tagalog} borrowing sarili ‘self’ used in place of kaugalingen or lawa:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref414723974} through \REF{bkm:Ref414775243} illustrate several prototypical examples of the reciprocal suffixes from the text corpus. Following this, some extended usages are described. A prototypical reciprocal construction involves an inherently transitive verb in a grammatically intransitive construction, with a reciprocal suffix on the verb and an Actor understood or explicited expressed as plural. The plural Actor may appear as a plural pronoun (\ref{bkm:Ref414723974}) or full RP (\ref{bkm:Ref414775363}):
Content 1: \gsrc Dimalas na \textbf{gasugatay} danen i naan ta Puerto. | \gll Dimalas na \textbf{ga-sugat-ay} danen i naan ta Puerto. | \gls bad.luck LK I.R-meet-REC 3P.ABS DEF.N SPAT.DEF NABS Puerto | \glt ‘(It was) bad luck that they met each other in Puerto.’
Content 2: \gsrc Paambaļ na tangkeban, sura din, may darwa na bato na \textbf{gatubangay} na may kulor na gainog-inog. | \gll Pa-ambaļ na tangkeb-an, sura din, may darwa na bato na \textbf{ga-tubang-ay} na may kulor na ga-inog-inog.\footnotemark{} | \gls T.R-say LK close-NR looks 3S.GEN EXT.IN two LK rock LK I.R-facing-REC LK EXT.IN color LK I.R-RED-red | \glt `What is called tangkeban, it looks like two rocks that have a reddish color \textbf{facing} \textbf{each} \textbf{other}.’
Content 3: \gsrc Dimalas na \textbf{gasugatay} danen i naan ta Puerto. | \gll Dimalas na \textbf{ga-sugat-ay} danen i naan ta Puerto. | \gls bad.luck LK I.R-meet-REC 3P.ABS DEF.N SPAT.DEF NABS Puerto | \glt ‘(It was) bad luck that they met each other in Puerto.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Pagkitaay} danen na tama en na mga umang, pasugiran en na kanen an daw Pwikan kisyem sellem \textbf{maglumbaay} dļagan.\\ | \gll \textbf{Pag-kita-ay} danen na tama en na mga umang, pa-sugid-an en na kanen an daw Pwikan kisyem sellem \textbf{mag-lumba-ay} dļagan. | \gls NR.ACT-see-REC 3P.ABS LK many CM LK PL hermit.crab T.R-tell-APL CM LK 3S.ABS DEF.M and sea.turtle tomorrow morning I.IR-race-REC run | \glt `When he and many hermit crabs met, (he) told (them) that he and Sea-turtle tomorrow morning would race each other running.’

Knowledge Point: Notice the first word in example \REF{bkm:Ref414775363} carries the reciprocal suffix -ay and also the action nominalization prefix pag{}- (see \chapref{chap:referringexpressions}, \sectref{sec:pag}). The sense of this action nominalization is “seeing each other”, or “meeting together”. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref501776847} and \REF{bkm:Ref501776849} illustrate the same verb with the reciprocal suffix as the main predicator of the clause:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Pagkitaay} danen na tama en na mga umang, pasugiran en na kanen an daw Pwikan kisyem sellem \textbf{maglumbaay} dļagan.\\ | \gll \textbf{Pag-kita-ay} danen na tama en na mga umang, pa-sugid-an en na kanen an daw Pwikan kisyem sellem \textbf{mag-lumba-ay} dļagan. | \gls NR.ACT-see-REC 3P.ABS LK many CM LK PL hermit.crab T.R-tell-APL CM LK 3S.ABS DEF.M and sea.turtle tomorrow morning I.IR-race-REC run | \glt `When he and many hermit crabs met, (he) told (them) that he and Sea-turtle tomorrow morning would race each other running.’
Content 2: \gsrc Uyi \textbf{kitaay} danen ta iya na sawa paagi man ta kaļat nang. | \gll U-yi ...-\textbf{kita-ay} danen ta iya na sawa paagi man ta kaļat nang. | \gls EMPH-D1ABS I.R-see-REC 3P.ABS NABS 3S.GEN LK spouse by.means too NABS rope only | \glt `These ones, he and his spouse met/saw each other by means of just a rope…’ (His wife lowered a rope out her window and they eloped.)
Content 3: \gsrc Mam, taan sadya kaw pirmi tak \textbf{gakitaay} kaw ta inyo na mga utod daw arey. | \gll Mam, taan sadya kaw pirmi tak \textbf{ga-kita-ay} kaw ta inyo na mga utod daw arey. | \gls Ma’am maybe happy 2P.ABS always because I.R-see-REC 2P.ABS NABS 2P.GEN LK PL sibling and friend | \glt `Ma’am, maybe you are always happy because you and your siblings and friends are seeing each other.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, the reciprocal may be used in a special sense when only one participant is acting (\ref{bkm:Ref402683617}-\ref{bkm:Ref118453570}). The free translations of these examples somewhat capture the sense of what this construction expresses, though they are not very literal. A literal translation of \REF{bkm:Ref402683617} would be something like “That is dancing of the woman with each other.” The idea is that the woman is dancing so well or vigorously that it seems as though there are several women dancing together. This is a very productive construction that can involve all kinds of actions and participants.
Content 1: \gsrc Nyan na \textbf{sayaway} ta bai an! | \gll Nyan na \textbf{sayaw-ay} ta bai an. | \gls D2ABS LK dance-REC NABS woman DEF.M | \glt ‘Wow! Look at the woman dance!’
Content 2: \gsrc Nyan na \textbf{basaay} ta libro bata an! | \gll Nyan na \textbf{basa-ay} ta libro bata an. | \gls D2ABS LK read-REC NABS book chld DEF.M | \glt ‘Wow! Look at the child reading books!’
Content 3: \gsrc Nyan na \textbf{sayaway} ta bai an! | \gll Nyan na \textbf{sayaw-ay} ta bai an. | \gls D2ABS LK dance-REC NABS woman DEF.M | \glt ‘Wow! Look at the woman dance!’
